member.summary: Stops listening for events.

member.name: M:Microsoft.O365.Security.ETW.KernelTrace.Start
member.summary: Starts listening for events from the enabled providers.
member.remarks:
This function is a blocking call. Whichever thread calls Start() is effectively donating itself to the ETW subsystem as the processing thread for events.
A side effect of this is that it is expected that Stop() will be called on a different thread.

member.name: M:Microsoft.O365.Security.ETW.KernelTrace.Open
member.summary: Opens a trace session.
member.remarks: This is an optional call before Start() if you need the trace registered with the ETW subsystem before you start processing events.

member.name: M:Microsoft.O365.Security.ETW.KernelTrace.SetTraceProperties(Microsoft.O365.Security.ETW.EventTraceProperties)
member.summary:
Sets the trace properties for a session. Must be called before Open()/Start(). See https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/etw/event-trace-properties for important details and restrictions.
Configurable properties are -> - BufferSize. In KB. The maximum buffer size is 1024 KB. - MinimumBuffers. Minimum number of buffers is two per processor* . - MaximumBuffers. - FlushTimer. How often, in seconds, the trace buffers are forcibly flushed. - LogFileMode. EVENT_TRACE_NO_PER_PROCESSOR_BUFFERING simulates a *single* sequential processor.
member.param: the to set on the trace

member.summary: Enables a provider for the given trace.
member.param: the to register with the current trace object

member.name: T:Microsoft.O365.Security.ETW.Filter
member.summary: Enables a more convenient mechanism to specify filters in managed C++/C#.
member.remarks: The idea here is that chains of complicated filters are built iteratively, using the methods on this class. These chains are passed into the native layer a single time, where they are used to do filtering before they are bubbled up to the managed layer.

member.name: T:krabs.testing.record_builder
member.summary: Enables creation of synthetic events in order to test client code.
member.remarks: This beast of a class enables the creation of EVENT_RECORD events for testing. The class accepts a collection of keyed pairs that are then packed into the event according to the schema on the local machine. Because a lot of this is Dark Arts kind of stuff, there really isn't a guarantee that this code works perfectly. Please file bugs.

member.name: T:krabs.testing.details.property_adder
member.summary: Provides a convenient syntax for adding properties to a record_builder.
member.remarks: Really shouldn't be used by client code. An instance of this should be handed out by a specific record_builder's `add_properties` method.

member.name: T:krabs.testing.extended_data_builder
member.summary:
Generates fake packed EVENT_HEADER_EXTENDED_DATA_ITEM structures to later add into test synth_record objects. These are not guaranteed to be indistinguishable from the real thing, just good enough to unit test code that reads/interprets extended data.
Note for testing: this builder just appends extended data structures, it won't stop you from breaking any API invariants, such as only one of a specific extended data item type.

member.name: T:krabs.testing.extended_data_thunk
member.summary: Since extended data items have to be packed later, we have to hold onto the data until we're ready to pack it.

member.name: T:krabs.testing.record_property_thunk
member.summary: Takes any value and turns it into a sequence of serialized bytes.
member.remarks: When we're composing an event, we need to store heterogeneous types in a collection while we wait until we know exactly how to pack the actual event. Because the actual EVENT_RECORD structure properties are packed into a byte collection, we take our cue from that and do similarly. We keep all of the random property byte blobs separate until we know the particular order to stash them in so we have less futzing to do later.

member.name: M:krabs.testing.details.how_many_bytes_to_fill(_TDH_IN_TYPE)

member.summary: Represents a single property of the record schema.
member.remarks: Noticeably absent from this property is the ability to ask what its value is. The reason for this is that this property instance is intended to work with synth_records, which don't always have data to correspond with properties. This class *cannot* return a value because there isn't always a value to return.

member.name: T:krabs.hexint32
member.summary: Used to discriminate between hex ints and regular ints in ETW events.
member.remarks: Q: Why in the world? I can't even. A: ETW differentiates between hexints and regular ints. When record_builder validates that the input type matches the type specified in the schema, getting this wrong will cause an exception. A quick little type wrapper like this lets us discriminate based on the type and everything turns out better.

member.name: T:krabs.event_filter
member.summary: Use this to provide event filtering before an event bubbles to specific callbacks.
member.remarks: Each event_filter has a single predicate (which can do complicated checks and logic on the event). All callbacks registered under the filter are invoked only if the predicate returns true for a given event.

member.name: M:krabs.guid_parser.parse_guid(System.SByte!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsSignUnspecifiedByte!System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst*,System.UInt32)
member.summary: * Parses GUID of "D" format. For example, the nil GUID would be "00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000". * See: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.guid.tostring?view=netframework-4.8 * * (str) must have at least (length) valid characters for memory safety. A null terminator is not * required. Instead, (length) is used for the bounds check. * * Returns the parsed GUID. Throws a std::runtime_error if there is a bounds error or format error. * * This function is for performance, to help deal with container ID extended data, which has no null * terminator, which would force us to clone the data to append a null terminator in order to use * existing GUID parsing functions. *
